Line 84: Line 84:
== Arrests ==
== Arrests ==
Rights activists have said that security agents have detained a number of protesters who were taking part in the "25th" demonstration. Twenty-five people have been arrested at [[Assiut]]<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypt-govt-security-detains-protesters-cairo-and-assiut|title=Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref>. According to Gamal Eid, director of the [[Arab Network for Human Rights Information]] (ANHRI). He noted that security agents seized banners hoisted by the protesters<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/>. Security sources said that Assuit's police arrested approximately 50 young people the night before "25th" demonstration and confined them in central security trucks<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/>. Meanwhile, sources at the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], said a number of the groupâs members have been detained in Mohandessin before heading to join "25th" demonstration<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/>. [[Ayman Nour]], the founder of the liberal opposition [[El-Ghad Party]], has tweeted that his son was taken by an unmarked car<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks">{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/26/egypt-protests|title=Egypt protests: 'We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks'|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>. Security forces in Cairo arrested Jack Shenker, a ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' news reporter, who secretly recorded his subsequent journey in a police van. Shenker was beaten several times along with numerous other protesters, after which they were loaded onto one of the security trucks. Shenker was crowded with 43 others in the vehicle, whose only ventilation were thick metal grates. They were driven for hours, and one of the protesters, who was diabetic, fell into a coma. Others futilely tried to get the truck driver to stop. After stopping near a government security headquarters far outside the city, a policeman unlocked the vehicle door, wanting a specific prisoner, Ayman Nour's son. The detainees managed to overpower the policeman and escape, flagging down cars to evacuate the unconscious man, while the rest worked to find their way back to Cairo.<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks"/>
Rights activists have said that security agents have detained a number of protesters who were taking part in the "25th" demonstration. Twenty-five people have been arrested at [[Assiut]]<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypt-govt-security-detains-protesters-cairo-and-assiut|title=Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref>. According to Gamal Eid, director of the [[Arab Network for Human Rights Information]] (ANHRI). He noted that security agents seized banners hoisted by the protesters<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/>. Security sources said that Assuit's police arrested approximately 50 young people the night before "25th" demonstration and confined them in central security trucks<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/>. Meanwhile, sources at the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], said a number of the groupâs members have been detained in Mohandessin before heading to join "25th" demonstration<ref name="Egypt govt security detains protesters in Cairo and Assiut"/>. [[Ayman Nour]], the founder of the liberal opposition [[El-Ghad Party]], has tweeted that his son was taken by an unmarked car<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks">{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/26/egypt-protests|title=Egypt protests: 'We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks'|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>. Security forces in Cairo arrested Jack Shenker, a ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' news reporter, who secretly recorded his subsequent journey in a police van. Shenker was beaten several times along with numerous other protesters, after which they were loaded onto one of the security trucks. Shenker was crowded with 43 others in the vehicle, whose only ventilation were thick metal grates. They were driven for hours, and one of the protesters, who was diabetic, fell into a coma. Others futilely tried to get the truck driver to stop. After stopping near a government security headquarters far outside the city, a policeman unlocked the vehicle door, wanting a specific prisoner, Ayman Nour's son. The detainees managed to overpower the policeman and escape, flagging down cars to evacuate the unconscious man, while the rest worked to find their way back to Cairo.<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks"/>
â   â
==Reports of Mubarak's family escape ==
  â
[[Gamal Mubarak]], Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak's son â who has been widely tipped as his successor â was reported to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January 2011.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the end' for Egypt's Mubarak as son and wife flee|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref>
  â
Officials did not immediately confirm the report that Gamal Mubarak has fled to the British capital with his wife and daughter aboard a private jet.<ref name="Adnkronos">{{cite web | url=http://www.adnkronos.com/IGN/Aki/English/Security/Egypt-Presidents-son-and-family-have-fled-to-the-UK_311591050596.html|title=Egypt: President's son and family 'have fled to the UK'|accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011|publisher=Adnkronos}}</ref><ref name="president's son, family flee to Britain">{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Egypt-presidents-son-family-flee-to-Britain/articleshow/7365922.cms|title=Egypt president's son, family flee to Britain|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[The Times of India]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee. <ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html</ref>
 
== Reactions ==
== Reactions ==
â
===International===
+
=== International ===
*{{flagicon|EU}} [[European Union]]'s foreign policy chief [[Catherine Ashton]] said Egyptian authorities should listen to their people, deal with their problems and respect their right to demonstrate, urging the "Egyptian authorities to respect and to protect the right of Egyptian citizens to manifest their political aspirations".<ref>http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST?SITE=DCTMS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT Egypt protesters clash for 2nd day with police</ref>
*{{flagicon|EU}} [[European Union]]'s foreign policy chief [[Catherine Ashton]] said Egyptian authorities should listen to their people, deal with their problems and respect their right to demonstrate, urging the "Egyptian authorities to respect and to protect the right of Egyptian citizens to manifest their political aspirations".<ref>http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST?SITE=DCTMS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT Egypt protesters clash for 2nd day with police</ref>
*{{flagicon|Germany}} [[Germany]]'s Foreign Minister [[Guido Westerwelle]] said he was "very concerned" and called on all concerned to show restraint.<ref>http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST?SITE=DCTMS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT Egypt protesters clash for 2nd day with police</ref>
*{{flagicon|Germany}} [[Germany]]'s Foreign Minister [[Guido Westerwelle]] said he was "very concerned" and called on all concerned to show restraint.<ref>http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST?SITE=DCTMS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT Egypt protesters clash for 2nd day with police</ref>

===Other domestic===
+
=== Domestic ===
  +
==== Reports of Mubarak's family escape ====
  +
[[Gamal Mubarak]], Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak's son â who has been widely tipped as his successor â was reported to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January 2011.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the end' for Egypt's Mubarak as son and wife flee|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref>
  +
Officials did not immediately confirm the report that Gamal Mubarak has fled to the British capital with his wife and daughter aboard a private jet.<ref name="Adnkronos">{{cite web | url=http://www.adnkronos.com/IGN/Aki/English/Security/Egypt-Presidents-son-and-family-have-fled-to-the-UK_311591050596.html|title=Egypt: President's son and family 'have fled to the UK'|accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011|publisher=Adnkronos}}</ref><ref name="president's son, family flee to Britain">{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Egypt-presidents-son-family-flee-to-Britain/articleshow/7365922.cms|title=Egypt president's son, family flee to Britain|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[The Times of India]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee. <ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html</ref>
  +   +
==== Other domestic ====
On 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread â Bloomberg<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> [[Twitter]] was taken off-line.<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/4773.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9206459/Twitter_blocked_in_Egypt_after_political_unrest</ref><ref>http://mashable.com/2011/01/25/twitter-blocked-in-egypt/</ref>
On 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread â Bloomberg<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> [[Twitter]] was taken off-line.<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/4773.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9206459/Twitter_blocked_in_Egypt_after_political_unrest</ref><ref>http://mashable.com/2011/01/25/twitter-blocked-in-egypt/</ref>
